chapter: Vascular System and Regional Circulation II

questions.question: What is the most powerful activator of the sympathetic vasomotor system?

options.A: Posture of the body against gravity

questions.explanation: The CNS ischemic response is considered the most powerful activator of the sympathetic vasomotor system.
questions.chapter_heading: Vascular System and Regional Circulation II

questions.question: During exercise, the organ experiencing the smallest decrease in blood flow is
questions.explanation: During exercise, the organ experiencing the smallest decrease in blood flow is the brain. During exercise, the coronary and cerebral systems are spared of the vasoconstrictor effect because both these circulatory areas have poor vasoconstrictor innervation.
questions.chapter_heading: Vascular System and Regional Circulation II

questions.question: An elderly man, with congestive cardiac failure, complains of shortness of breath when lying down. What is the mechanism behind this symptom?

options.B: Reservoir function of veins in lower limbs.

questions.explanation: The given scenario describes orthopnea in congestive heart failure. It is due to the reservoir function of pulmonary veins. Orthopnea is dyspnea occurring in the recumbent position. It results from redistribution of fluid from the splanchnic circulation and lower extremities (increased venous return) into the heart during recumbency. This increased venous return is not put out by the left ventricle and hence pools in the pulmonary veins that act as capacitance vessels (reservoir function), adding to the already congested pulmonary vasculature, resulting in breathing difficulty.
questions.chapter_heading: Vascular System and Regional Circulation II

questions.question: The interstitial fluid pressure is negative in
questions.explanation: The interstitial fluid pressure is negative in the lungs. The interstitial fluid pressure is slightly negative in the body except in the encapsulated organs. It is positive in rigid closed compartments - bone marrow, brain, and encapsulated organs - kidney, skeletal muscle. This is due to the fact that in the kidneys, high-pressure vessels push the interstitial fluid against an unyielding fibrous capsule, raising the pressure. The same principle applies to skeletal muscle surrounded by layers of fascia.
questions.chapter_heading: Vascular System and Regional Circulation II

questions.question: Blood flow per minute in pulmonary circulation is

options.A: Less than flow through systemic circulation
options.B: More than flow through systemic circulation
options.C: Equal to flow through systemic circulation

questions.explanation: Blood flow per minute in the pulmonary circulation is equal to flow through the systemic circulation, so as to provide a continuous blood supply to the body. If the flow rate is slower in the pulmonary circulation than systemic, then the left ventricle would soon empty completely. If the flow rate is faster in the pulmonary circulation, then the left ventricle would soon be overloaded. Please note that because some blood flows into the bronchial arteries, the actual flow through the pulmonary circulation is slightly less than the flow through the systemic circulation. However, this question aims to state that the blood flow through both pulmonary and systemic circulation is largely equal.
questions.chapter_heading: Vascular System and Regional Circulation II

questions.question: A patient was receiving a red cell transfusion following hip arthroplasty. Midway through the transfusion, she developed signs and symptoms of shock. What is the type of shock seen in her?
questions.explanation: The shock due to a transfusion reaction is distributive shock. During transfusion reaction, there is decreased systemic vascular resistance due to system-wide vasodilation mediated by the release of histamine by mast cells in response to antigen-bound IgE, leading to distributive shock. Types of circulatory shock: Hypovolemic shock: due to decreased blood in the vascular compartment. E.g., hemorrhage, dehydration. Cardiogenic shock: due to decreased capacity of the heart to pump. E.g., any pathology of the heart decreasing its ability to maintain cardiac output. Obstructive shock: due to conditions causing obstruction to blood flow in the lungs and heart. E.g.: pulmonary embolism. Distributive/vasculogenic shock: excessive vasodilation leading to impaired organ perfusion. E.g.: septic shock, SIRS, transfusion reaction, Addisonian crisis, neurogenic shock. Three stages of shock: Non-progressive: also called compensated shock, where normal compensatory mechanisms eventually cause full recovery without help from outside therapy. Progressive: also called non-compensated, without therapy it gets steadily worse. Irreversible: even therapy is inadequate to save life.
questions.chapter_heading: Vascular System and Regional Circulation II

questions.question: During fetal life, blood vessel with maximum concentration of oxygen is
questions.explanation: During fetal life, blood vessel with maximum concentration of oxygen is the umbilical vein. The placenta, umbilical vein, umbilical cord (contains umbilical artery and umbilical vein), mixed blood travels to the head and body, and back to the placenta via the aorta. The ductus arteriosus connects the aorta with the pulmonary artery, further shunting blood away from the lungs and into the aorta. The foramen ovale allows oxygenated blood in the right atrium to reach the left atrium. Oxygenated blood from the placenta enters the right atrium via the inferior vena cava. The ductus venosus shunts oxygenated blood from the placenta away from the semi-functional liver and toward the heart. Blood arrives via the umbilical vein.
questions.chapter_heading: Vascular System and Regional Circulation II

questions.question: Progressive hemorrhagic shock is characterized by

options.A: Blood clots in the small blood vessels

questions.explanation: Progressive hemorrhagic shock is characterized by the presence of blood clots in the small blood vessels. The initiating cause of this blockage is sluggish blood flow in the microvessels. Tissue metabolites plus other deterioration products from the ischemic tissues cause minute clots in these vessels. Thus, the microvasculature gets blocked by the sludged blood. In progressive hemorrhagic shock, there is increased lysosomal activity, decreased active transport of sodium, and tissue acidosis.
questions.chapter_heading: Vascular System and Regional Circulation II

questions.question: During rest, blood flow through skeletal muscle averages
questions.explanation: During rest, blood flow through skeletal muscle averages 3-4 mL/min/100 g of muscle. The resting blood flow through various organs in a 63 kg adult man with a mean arterial pressure of 90 mmHg and O2 consumption of 250 mL/min is given below. Region: Blood flow (mL/min) - Liver: 1500, Kidneys: 1260, Brain: 750, Skeletal muscle: 840, Heart muscle: 250.
questions.chapter_heading: Vascular System and Regional Circulation II

questions.question: The type of shock that has high cardiac output is
questions.explanation: Septic shock is characterized by high cardiac output. High cardiac output in septic shock is caused by arteriolar dilation in the infected tissues and a high metabolic rate and vasodilation (resulting from bacterial toxin stimulating cellular metabolism and from high body temperature).
questions.chapter_heading: Vascular System and Regional Circulation II

questions.question: Thin-walled and delicate vessels like capillaries are less prone to rupture. This can be explained by
questions.explanation: Thin-walled and delicate vessels like capillaries are less prone to rupture, and this can be explained by Laplace's law. The principal reason for these vessels' relative invulnerability is their small diameter. The protective effect of small size, in this case, is an example of the law of Laplace. Laplace's law states that tension in the wall of a cylinder (T) is equal to the product of the transmural pressure (P) and the radius (r) divided by the wall thickness (w): T = Pr/w. As the tissue pressure is low, P is equated to the pressure inside the blood vessel. W can be ignored as well, since capillaries are thin-walled. Hence: P = T/r. In a thin-walled viscus, P = T divided by the two principal radii of curvature of the viscus: P = T(1/r1+1/r2). In a cylinder such as a blood vessel, one radius is infinite, so P = T/r. Hence, the smaller the radius, the lower is the tension necessary in the wall to balance the distending pressure.
questions.chapter_heading: Vascular System and Regional Circulation II

questions.question: The relationship between the flow in a long narrow tube, the viscosity of the fluid, and the radius of the tube is expressed mathematically by
questions.explanation: The relationship between the flow in a long narrow tube, the viscosity of the fluid, and the radius of the tube is expressed mathematically by Poiseuille's law. Poiseuille-Hagen formula: F = (PA-PB) * π * r^4 / (8 * η * L), where F = flow, PA - PB = pressure difference between two ends of the tube, η = viscosity, r = radius of tube, L = length of tube.
questions.chapter_heading: Vascular System and Regional Circulation II

questions.question: In the 2 vessels shown below, assume the pressure along both the vessels is the same and both follow a linear flow pattern. What will be the amount of blood flow in A compared to B
questions.explanation: The relationship between the flow in a long narrow tube, the viscosity of the fluid, and the radius of the tube is expressed mathematically in the formula called Poiseuille's law: Poiseuille's law Q = (ΔPπr^4)/(8nl). Q - Volume flux, ΔP - Change in pressure, r - Pipe or vessel radius, n - Viscosity, l - Pipe or vessel length. Blood flow (F) inside the vessel depends on: • Pressure difference: directly proportional, • Viscosity: inversely proportional, • Radius: directly proportional to the fourth power, • Length of the vessel: inversely proportional. Here, the radius is doubled, so the flow increases by 2 to the power of 4 = 16. The length of the vessel is also doubled, so the flow decreases by half (÷2) = 8.
questions.chapter_heading: Vascular System and Regional Circulation II

questions.question: Which of the following statements is false about Cuthbertson's metabolic ebb and flow responses to trauma?

options.A: The "ebb" phase is associated with a decline in body temperature and oxygen consumption.
options.B: The "flow" phase occurs after resuscitation from a state of shock.
options.C: The "ebb" phase is aimed at reducing posttraumatic energy depletion.
options.D: The "ebb" phase leads to activation of the innate immune system and induction of the hepatic acute-phase response.

questions.explanation: The "flow" phase (not "ebb") leads to activation of the innate immune system and induction of the hepatic acute-phase response. Cuthbertson's ebb and flow response to trauma: The "ebb" phase lasts for a brief duration and is associated with a decline in body temperature and oxygen consumption, aimed at reducing post-traumatic energy depletion. The "flow" phase occurs after resuscitation from a state of shock, which leads to an increased metabolic turnover, activation of the innate immune system and induction of the hepatic acute-phase response. This hypercatabolic condition leads to a significantly increased oxygen consumption and energy expenditure.
questions.chapter_heading: Vascular System and Regional Circulation II

questions.question: Hering's nerve finally relays in
questions.explanation: The Hering's nerve terminates in the medulla (Tractus solitarius). Baroreceptor reflexes: Carotid baroreceptors → Hering's nerve → the glossopharyngeal nerve → Tractus solitarius in the medulla. Aortic baroreceptors → Vagus nerve → Tractus solitarius in the medulla. Baroreceptor system: Glossopharyngeal nerve, Hering's nerve, External carotid artery, Internal carotid artery, Carotid body, Carotid sinus, Common carotid artery, Vagus nerve, Aortic baroreceptors.
questions.chapter_heading: Vascular System and Regional Circulation II

questions.question: Microcirculation consists of
questions.explanation: Microcirculation consists of capillaries, arterioles, venules, and terminal lymphatics.
questions.chapter_heading: Vascular System and Regional Circulation II

questions.question: Mayer waves are due to

options.A: Variation of arterial pressure during each systole.
options.B: Variation of arterial pressure due to reflex changes in nervous control of blood pressure
options.C: Variation of arterial pressure with changes in respiration.
options.D: Variation of arterial pressure with postural change.

questions.explanation: Mayer waves are due to the variation of arterial pressure due to reflex changes in nervous control of blood pressure. The most important mechanisms are as follows: I: Baroreceptor and chemoreceptor reflex: High pressure excites the baroreceptors --> inhibits sympathetic nervous system and lowers the pressure --> The decreased pressure, in turn, reduces the baroreceptor stimulation --> elevating the pressure to a high value (the response is not instantaneous, it is delayed until a few seconds later). This high pressure then initiates another cycle, and the oscillation continues. II: Oscillation of the CNS Ischemic Response: The cerebrospinal fluid pressure is raised to 160 mm Hg --> causes compression of cerebral blood vessels --> cerebral ischemia --> CNS ischemic pressure response raises the arterial pressure up to 200 mm Hg --> the brain ischemia is relieved and the sympathetic nervous system becomes inactive --> the arterial pressure falls rapidly back to a much lower value, causing brain ischemia once again --> initiates another rise in pressure. This chain of events repeats itself cyclically as long as the cerebrospinal fluid pressure remains elevated.
questions.chapter_heading: Vascular System and Regional Circulation II

questions.question: Vasomotion refers to

options.A: Venous drainage to the RA by contraction of the IVC.
options.B: Intermittent contraction of metarterioles and precapillary sphincters.
options.C: Pulsatile action of arteries which helps in lymphatic drainage.
options.D: Systolic pumping of blood by the heart into the aorta.

questions.explanation: Vasomotion means intermittent contraction of metarterioles and precapillary sphincters. Blood usually does not flow continuously through the capillaries. Instead, it flows intermittently, turning on and off every few seconds or minutes. This is vasomotion, which is responsible for the flow of blood in capillaries. The main regulatory factor for vasomotion is tissue oxygen concentration. Components of the microcirculation include: arteriole, precapillary sphincters, smooth muscle cells, venule, metarteriole, and capillaries, as well as arteriovenous bypass.
questions.chapter_heading: Vascular System and Regional Circulation II

questions.question: Ejection fraction in resting healthy man is approximately
questions.explanation: Ejection fraction in resting healthy man is approximately 0.6.The fraction of the end-diastolic volume that is ejected is called the ejection fraction, usually equalto about 60 %.
questions.chapter_heading: Vascular System and Regional Circulation II

questions.question: The relation between ventricular stroke volume and end-diastolic volume is explained by
questions.explanation: The relation between ventricular stroke volume and end-diastolic volume is explained by Frank-Starling's law. The length-tension relationship in cardiac muscle is similar to that in skeletal muscle. When the muscle is stretched, the developed tension increases to a maximum and then declines as the stretch becomes more extreme. Starling stated that 'the energy of contraction is proportional to the initial length of the cardiac muscle fibre'. When cardiac output is regulated by changes in cardiac fibre length, this is referred to as heterometric regulation. Conversely, regulation due to changes in contractility independent of length is called homometric regulation.
questions.chapter_heading: Vascular System and Regional Circulation II

questions.question: The best index of preload is
questions.explanation: The best index of preload is left ventricular end diastolic volume.Preload - load that the left ventricle carries before the systole.Left ventricular end diastolic volume - blood remaining at the end of diastole, which determinesstretch of the ventricle and thus force of contraction as explained by frank starlings law.497
questions.chapter_heading: Vascular System and Regional Circulation II
